Treaty Name: Antarctic Treaty
Reason: The Treaty obligates parties to only use Antarctica for peaceful purposes. Military activities are prohibited, including the testing of weapons, nuclear explosions, and the disposal of radioactive waste in Antarctica.

Treaty Name: Treaty Banning Nuclear Tests in the Atmosphere, in Outer Space and Under Water (Partial Test Ban Treaty) (PTBT)
Reason: The PTBT requires parties to abstain from carrying out nuclear explosions in any environment where such explosions cause radioactive debris outside the limits of the State that conducts an explosion.

Treaty Name: Treaty for the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons in Latin America and the Caribbean (LANWFZ) (Tlatelolco Treaty)
Countries Signed: 33 States in Latin America and Caribbean
Reason: The Tlatelolco Treaty prohibits Latin American states from acquiring, possessing, developing, testing or using nuclear weapons, and prohibits other countries from storing and deploying nuclear weapons on their territories.

Treaty Name: Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT)
Reason: The NPT is a treaty aimed at limiting the spread of nuclear weapons through the three elements of non-proliferation, disarmament, and peaceful use of nuclear energy.

Treaty Name: Treaty on the Prohibition of the Emplacement of Nuclear Weapons and Other Weapons of Mass Destruction on the Seabed and Ocean Floor and in the Subsoil Thereof (Seabed Treaty)
Reason: The treaty prevents placement of NBC weapons on the seabed and ocean floor to eliminate the possibility of an underwater arms race and promote the peaceful exploration of water bodies.

Treaty Name: Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT I)
Reason: SALT refers to two rounds of talks between the US and the USSR on nuclear arms control. SALT I (1969-1972) led to the ABM Treaty

Treaty Name: Treaty on the Limitation of Anti-Ballistic Missile Systems (ABM Treaty)
Reason: cease construction of a national anti-ballistic missile system to limit the development and deployment of defensive missiles

Treaty Name: Treaty between the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics on Underground Nuclear Explosion for Peaceful Purposes (PNE Treaty)
Reason: allows the United States and the USSR to conduct underground peaceful nuclear explosions at any location under their jurisdiction or control.

Treaty Name: Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT II)
Reason: SALT refers to two rounds of talks between the US and the USSR on nuclear arms control. SALT II lasted from 1972-1979

Treaty Name: South Pacific Nuclear-Free Zone (SPNFZ) Treaty of Rarotonga
Countries Signed: Australia, Cook Islands, Fiji, Kiribati, Nauru, New Zealand, Niue, Papa New Guinea, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tonga, Tuvalu, Vanuatu
Reason: The treaty prohibits nuclear explosive devices in the South Pacific. It is the second treaty to establish a NWFZ, and also bans the testing and use of nuclear explosive technologies.

Treaty Name: Treaty between The United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics on the Elimination of Their Intermediate-range and Shorter-range Missiles (INF Treaty)
Reason: bilateral agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union. It was the first treaty to reduce nuclear arms instead of establishing an arms ceiling

Treaty Name: India-Pakistan Non-Attack Agreement
Reason: refrain from causing destruction to any nuclear installation in each country

Treaty Name: Treaty between The United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics on Strategic Offensive Reductions (START I)
Reason: START I limited the number of strategic nuclear delivery vehicles and warheads

Treaty Name: Join Declaration of South and North Korea on the Denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula
Reason: agreed not to possess, produce, or use nuclear weapons, and prohibited uranium enrichment and plutonium reprocessing

Treaty Name: Nuclear-Weapon-Free Status of Mongolia
Reason: The NWF Status prohibits any state from: 1. the development, possession, or control over nuclear weapons in Mongolia; 2. transporting nuclear weapons in Mongolia; 3. disposing radioactive material in Mongolia.

Treaty Name: Treaty between The United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics on Strategic Offensive Reductions (START II)
Reason: START II complemented START I by attempting to establish further limits on strategic nuclear weapons for each party

Treaty Name: US-DPRK Agreed Framework
Reason: called for replacing a North Korean nuclear reactor in exchange for normalizing relations and other incentives

Treaty Name: Southeast Asian Nuclear-Weapon-Free-Zone (SEANWFZ) Treaty ) Bangkok Treaty)
Countries Signed: Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam
Reason: ASEAN members established the treaty, a critical component of ASEANÕs Declaration on a Zone of Peace, Freedom, and Neutrality, to ensure the absence of nuclear explosive devices in the region.

Treaty Name: African Nuclear-Weapon-Free-Zone (ANWFZ) Treaty (Pelindaba Treaty)
Reason: not to develop, manufacture, acquire, or possess any nuclear explosive device. Parties may engage in peaceful nuclear activities and must conclude safeguards agreements with the IAEA.

Treaty Name: Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT)
Reason: The CTBT prohibits nuclear weapon test explosions. It has not yet entered into force, since three of the 44 required states have yet to sign it and five to ratify it.

Treaty Name: Lahore Declaration
Reason: reduce the risk of accidental or unauthorized use of nuclear weapons

Treaty Name: Strategic Offensive Reductions Treaty (SORT)
Reason: mutually decrease and limit strategic nuclear weapons, with each party reserving the right to determine the structure of its strategic offensive arms

Treaty Name: International Convention on the Suppression of Acts of Nuclear Terrorism
Reason: It criminalizes the planning, threatening, or carrying out acts of nuclear terrorism

Treaty Name: Central Asia Nuclear-Weapon-Free-Zone (CANWFZ)
Reason: cannot develop, acquire, possess, or control any nuclear weapon or nuclear explosive device, or carry out nuclear weapon tests. They also pledge to prevent nuclear explosions.

Treaty Name: Treaty between The United States of America and the Russian Federation on Measures for the Further Reduction and Limitation of Strategic Offensive Arms (New START)
Reason: New START is the most recent agreement for nuclear arms reduction between the United States and Russia, establishing a limit on deployed strategic warheads

Treaty Name: Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons
Reason: The Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons bans the use, possession, development, testing, deployment and transfer of nuclear weapons under international law.

Treaty Name: Proposed Fissile Material (Cut-off) Treaty (FMCT)
Reason: The proposed treaty is intended to prohibit the production of fissile material

Treaty Name: Proposed Internationally Legally-Binding Negative Security Assurances (NSAs)
Reason: NSAs are the promise of nuclear-weapon States not to use or threaten nuclear weapons against non-nuclear-weapon States.

Treaty Name: Proposed Nuclear Weapons Convention (NWC)
Reason: The proposed NWC, modeled on the CWC and BTWC, is intended to prohibit the development, testing, production, transfer, use and threat of use of nuclear weapons by all parties.

Treaty Name: Proposed Prevention of an Arms Race in Space (PAROS) Treaty
Reason: A PAROS treaty would build on the efforts of the 1967 Outer Space Treaty to preserve space for peaceful uses by committing States Parties to refrain from placing objects carrying any type of weapon into orbit, installing weapons on celestial bodies, and threatening to use force against objects in outer space.

Countries Ratified: Of the 44 States included in Annex 2 required for entry into force of the CTBT, all have signed with the exceptions of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK), India, and Pakistan. Five of the 44 Annex 2 States have signed but not ratified the CTBT; they are China, Egypt, Iran, Israel, and the United States. The United States and China are the only remaining NPT Nuclear Weapon States that have not ratified the CTBT.
